title: Russian Playwright and Theater Director Are Convicted of ‘Justifying Terrorism’
summary: A theater director and playwright were sentenced to prison, a stark indication of the increasing suppression of free speech since Russia’s attack on Ukraine, their lawyers and critics say.
author: Valerie Hopkins
tags: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

title: Middle East Crisis: Statements From Netanyahu and Hamas Narrow Hopes for a Truce in Gaza
summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire, and Hamas said that the continued fighting risked returning “the negotiating process to point zero.”
author: The New York Times

title: France Learns a New Word: Ungovernable
summary: Far from producing a “clarification,” President Emmanuel Macron’s snap election has yielded a muddle that could take months to sort out.
author: Roger Cohen

title: Russian Strike Destroys Children’s Hospital in Kyiv
summary: President Volodymyr Zelensky said Russia launched at least 40 missiles at targets across Ukraine, including the country’s largest children’s hospital.
author: Marc Santora and Brendan Hoffman

title: France Has No Majority After the Elections. What Happens Next?
summary: No party got an absolute majority in the National Assembly. Here are some of the ways the country could escape political gridlock. None are easy.
author: Aurelien Breeden

title: France Reacts to Runoff Election Results
summary: The final tally confirms that the left has the most seats in the National Assembly, with the far right third. Now, there’s a scramble to figure out a way forward.
author: Catherine Porter

title: What Happened in France’s Election? 5 Key Takeaways.
summary: It was a day of big surprises in France, with the left surging unexpectedly, the far right falling far short of expectations and the question of who will be the next prime minister still unclear.
author: Adam Nossiter and Aurelien Breeden

title: French 2024 Parliamentary Election Results in Maps and Charts
summary: No party secured an absolute majority in legislative elections on Sunday, leaving France headed for gridlock or political instability.
author: Matthew Bloch, Andrew Park, Urvashi Uberoy and Véronique Brossier

title: Modi to Meet Putin in Moscow as India Charts Its Own Course
summary: India is determined to keep its close ties to Russia despite pressure from the West. Russia sees the meeting as a chance to show it still has influential friends.
author: Anupreeta Das and Hari Kumar

title: Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Leader, Surprises Europe Again With Visit to China
summary: Mr. Orban said his meeting with President Xi Jinping was part of a “peace mission” for Ukraine. But both leaders want to offset Western power.
author: Chris Buckley and Andrew Higgins

title: Soaring Temperatures and Profit Seekers Amplify Dangers on the Hajj
summary: “The halls felt like they were on fire,” one Jordanian woman said of her accommodations after she opted to take a cheaper travel package for “unregistered” pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.
author: Rana F. Sweis, Emad Mekay and Lynsey Chutel

title: Hurdles Star Trey Cunningham Comes Out as Gay
summary: Trey Cunningham said friends and peers reacted to his decision to come out with a shrug. He wishes the same was true for other men in elite sports.
author: Rory Smith

title: In Rafah, We Saw Destruction and the Limits of Israel’s Gaza Strategy
summary: Months after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu declared that “victory is within reach,” the Israeli military escorted journalists into parts of a devastated Gazan city.
author: Adam Goldman

title: Masoud Pezeshkian, Iran’s New President, Raises Hope for a Diplomatic Opening
summary: Masoud Pezeshkian, a reformist, wants warmer relations with the West, with the goal of ending sanctions. But his powers are strictly limited.
author: Lara Jakes

title: More Ukrainians May Die in Attacks on Medical Sites in 2024, W.H.O. Data Suggest
summary: A Russian missile strike on a children’s hospital in Kyiv on Monday highlighted the growing number of deadly attacks on medical facilities, vehicles and workers.
author: Eve Sampson

title: After an Election Surprise, What’s Next for France?
summary: Far from producing clarity, the snap election called by President Emmanuel Macron of France has yielded a muddle that could take months to sort out.
author: Roger Cohen, Rebecca Suner, James Surdam and Christina Shaman

title: Tuesday Briefing: What Comes Next for France
summary: Plus, President Biden’s crucial week.
author: Daniel E. Slotnik

title: The Surgeon
summary: A single image captures a day of horror at a children’s hospital in Ukraine hit by a Russian missile.
author: Brendan Hoffman

title: Biden Administration Rule Would Increase Authority to Block Foreign Deals
summary: The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States proposed a rule that would make it harder for foreigners to buy land near military bases.
author: Alan Rappeport

title: U.S. Creates High-Tech Global Supply Chains to Blunt Risks Tied to China
summary: The Biden administration is trying to get foreign companies to invest in chip-making in the United States and more countries to set up factories to do final assembly and packaging.
author: Edward Wong and Ana Swanson

title: The Killer Stalking Sri Lanka’s Men
summary: Climate change and contaminated water have combined to create an epidemic of kidney disease.
author: Kang-Chun Cheng and Apoorva Mandavilli

title: Monday Briefing
summary: The left surges in French elections.
author: Natasha Frost

title: How the Far-Right National Rally Did in France’s Elections
summary: The party fell short of expectations but had captured its highest number of National Assembly seats.
author: Ségolène Le Stradic and Matthew Mpoke Bigg

title: France’s New Popular Front Was Formed to Keep Far Right From Power
summary: The left-wing alliance includes the divisive Jean-Luc Mélenchon, a combative politician who has been accused of antisemitism.
author: Catherine Porter

title: Monday Briefing: Left Surges in French Election
summary: Plus, a reformist will be Iran’s next president.
author: Daniel E. Slotnik

title: France’s Campaign Season Was Marred by Racist Attacks and Violent Acts
summary: Gérald Darmanin, France’s interior minister, said that more than 50 people — including candidates, their substitutes or supporters — had been “physically assaulted” during the campaign.
author: Catherine Porter

title: French Election Yields Deadlock as Left Surges and Far Right Comes Up Short
summary: The outcome left no party with an absolute majority and France bracing for potential political paralysis.
author: Roger Cohen

title: France Could Be Headed for Political Gridlock After Election
summary: Experts said the country could be headed for months of political instability, with the National Assembly divided into three major blocs that appear unable to work with the others.
author: Aurelien Breeden

title: Here Are the Key Players in France’s 2024 Election
summary: The vote has turned into a race between the two main opponents of President Emmanuel Macron’s Renaissance party: the far-right National Rally and the New Popular Front, a left-wing coalition.
author: Catherine Porter

title: The Windmills Are Back Up on the Moulin Rouge
summary: The Paris landmark has completed its restoration after the blades fell off this spring — and just in time for the Summer Olympic Games to begin.
author: Amelia Nierenberg

title: Israelis Call for a Cease-Fire Deal and Elections After 9 Months of War
summary: A day of nationwide anti-government protests comes amid signs of progress toward a truce and hostage deal with Hamas, as well as continued fighting.
author: Isabel Kershner

title: Deadly Flooding and Landslides in Nepal
summary: In this monsoon season, so far there have been more than 60 weather-related fatalities. With roads cut off and more rain expected, the toll could rise.
author: Bhadra Sharma

title: New Plan to Target Russia’s Oil Revenue Brings Debate in White House
summary: Treasury officials want to impose penalties on tankers that help Russian oil evade sanctions. White House aides worry that risks making gasoline more expensive.
author: Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

title: Farage and the Future of the U.K.’s Conservative Party
summary: In the shadow of Labour’s landslide victory over the upended Conservatives, Nigel Farage’s small insurgent right-wing party, Reform U.K., is on a roll.
author: Stephen Castle

title: Ukraine Tries to Stay Neutral in Political Dogfight Between Trump and Biden
summary: With President Biden’s future unclear, Donald J. Trump’s support uncertain and a major NATO meeting looming, Ukrainian leaders are straining to keep their balance.
author: Marc Santora and Steven Erlanger

title: Pakistan Withers Under Deadly Heat and Fears the Coming Rains
summary: Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city, endured days of temperatures above 100 Fahrenheit, made worse by power cuts and high humidity.
author: Zia ur-Rehman

title: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike Is Re-elected in Race With 56 Candidates
summary: A ridiculous number of candidates contended to be governor of Tokyo and its surrounding prefecture. Many were not even trying to win.
author: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya

title: Turnout Is High as France’s Snap Election Enters Its Final Hours
summary: The vote will determine the composition of France’s National Assembly, and the future of President Emmanuel Macron’s second term.
author: Aurelien Breeden

title: 4 Takeaways From Iran’s Presidential Runoff
summary: The victory of the reformist candidate, Masoud Pezeshkian, is expected to bring change, but to what extent is still an open question.
author: Lynsey Chutel

title: Hamas’s Cease-Fire Proposal Includes a Familiar Sticking Point
summary: Hamas wants assurances that Israel won’t restart the war after some hostages come home. Israel says it needs the option.
author: Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Julian E. Barnes

title: Wayne S. Smith, a Leading Critic of the Embargo on Cuba, Dies at 91
summary: A former State Department official, he resigned in protest in 1982 over Cuba policy, then spent decades trying to rebuild relations with the island nation.
author: Clay Risen

title: Mythical Sword’s Disappearance Brings Mystery to French Village
summary: Legend says the Durandal sword had been stuck in a French hillside for nearly 1,300 years. When it went missing in June, an investigation to find France’s Excalibur began.
author: Hank Sanders and William Lamb

title: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer Is About to Get a Crash Course in Statecraft
summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer will travel to a NATO summit this coming week, where he will represent a rare point of centrist stability among unsettled allies.
author: Mark Landler

title: Facing New ‘Greenwashing’ Law, an Oil Industry Website Goes Dark
summary: Oil sands companies pushing a carbon capture project shut down their website after a law banning misleading environmental claims was passed.
author: Ian Austen

title: Developing Your Taste
summary: The meals that we love are informed as much by the experience of eating them as by the flavor of the food itself.
author: Melissa Kirsch

title: In the French Countryside, the Far-Right National Rally Has Risen
summary: In northern Burgundy, services have collapsed and the far-right National Rally has risen.
author: Roger Cohen

title: What Do Bagged Chickens Have to Do With Sliced Cheese?
summary: Both have gotten caught up in fights over plastic packaging. When Costco recently tried to trim its plastic use by selling rotisserie chickens in bags, some shoppers disapproved.
author: Hiroko Tabuchi

title: Abductions Rattle Kenya as Anti-Government Protests Continue
summary: Dozens of activists say they were snatched from their homes or off the streets by hooded, armed men. Some are still missing, and the disappearances have unnerved a nation long seen as a pillar of stability.
author: Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
tags: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

title: Violence, Rape, Thirst, Even Organ Theft: Migrants Face Lethal Risks in Africa
summary: The danger to migrants while crossing the Mediterranean is well documented, but an earlier phase of their trek, across the Sahel and the Sahara, is deadlier, researchers say in a new report.
author: Eve Sampson
tags: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

title: Can Foreigners Handle the Heat? Mexico City Debates Milder Salsas.
summary: As more foreigners, especially Americans, visit or move to Mexico City, some taco shops have lowered the heat in their sauces. Not everyone is happy.
author: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas

title: In Ukraine, Killings of Unarmed Russians Divide a U.S.-Led Unit
summary: A German medic said he was so troubled that he confronted his commander. Others boasted about killings in a group chat.
author: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
tags: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

title: Masoud Pezeshkian Wins Iran’s Presidential Election
summary: Masoud Pezeshkian, a cardiac surgeon and relative moderate in the ruling establishment, defeated an ultraconservative former nuclear negotiator in a runoff.
author: Farnaz Fassihi

title: Andrew Tate Is Allowed to Leave Romania in Latest Court Decision
summary: The court in Bucharest ruled that Mr. Tate and his brother, who are facing human trafficking and rape charges, must remain in the European Union as they await trial, his lawyer said.
author: Emily Schmall

title: New Popular Front Scored Big in France’s Vote. Who Are Its Members?
summary: Parties on the left were so fractious, they broke up their alliance months ago, but the possibility of a government controlled by the far right drew them back together.
author: Catherine Porter

title: Labour Won a U.K. Landslide. Why Doesn’t It Feel Like That?
summary: Keir Starmer’s party won a huge majority in parliament. But the new prime minister faces a fractious and volatile public.
author: Mark Landler

title: Reform U.K.’s Success Is Latest Sign of Strength for Europe’s Far Right
summary: The insurgent anti-immigration party led by Nigel Farage secured around 14 percent of the vote in Britain’s general election, though it has won only five parliamentary seats.
author: Stephen Castle

title: Count Binface and Elmo Provided a Bit of Comic Relief in Britain’s Elections
summary: As has long been the tradition in Britain, the elections included various joke candidates who often run against prominent politicians.
author: Claire Moses

title: Who Is Angela Rayner, Britain’s Deputy Prime Minister?
summary: While politics in Britain have traditionally been dominated by the country’s elites, Ms. Rayner has taken a less traditional route to the top.
author: Megan Specia

title: Vatican Excommunicates Its Former Ambassador to the U.S.
summary: Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, who was informed of his excommunication on Friday, has long been a vocal critic of Pope Francis.
author: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
